results.title: Yorke Peninsula
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description: The sea in its various moods is the central “character” in this exploration of the scenery and recreational opportunities of Yorke Peninsula in South Australia. The agricultural and mining background of this region adds a further dimension to its natural pleasures.

results.title: Who killed Jenny Langby?
results.creator_credit: John Morris, South Australian Film Corporation and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description: An award winning portrayal by director Donald Crombie of a suburban mother who is a victim of the pressures and pace of modern urban life. The domestic situation before and after her suicide are re-created for a dramatic examination of cause and effect. Docu-drama presented as an interview by Anne Deveson.

results.title: Way ahead
results.creator_credit: Kim Dalton, South Australian Film Corporation and Robert Walker
results.brief_description: A look at the ever increasing problems of the motor car and its alternative, public transport. New improvements in public transport systems throughout the world are examined. Other new ideas, still in the planning stages, are also shown. Animation is ;used to show a possible futurisitic solution of personalised rapid transit. Cinematography by John Leake.

results.title: Somewhere to go
results.creator_credit: Brian Bergin, John Morris and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Hugh Hudson, South Australian Minister for Education, discusses the establishment of school-based community centres in two Adelaide suburbs, Thebarton and Angle Park. The surveys and plans, initiated in mid 1973, show that an essential feature of the planning process was the participation of the communities concerned.

results.title: Safety in your hands
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Jill Robb, John Fitzgerald and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1974 film examines the responsibility of each worker for their own safety in the workplace. The film focuses particularly on protection of hands and eyes in industrial settings, showing a variety of machines operated by people. It demonstrates how untidiness, inattention, overconfidence and failure to use safety precautions such as safety glasses when operating these machines can lead to accidents. Footage of industrial workplaces is interspersed with footage of everyday accidents similarly caused by mess, distraction and overconfidence.

Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: A Taste of Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Ron Way and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: An award-winning film of some of Adelaide’s fine restaurants and hotels; a tour laced together with delightful glimpses into some of the colourful, charming, little-known and well-known aspects of this unspoiled, unhurried city.

results.title: Safe driving: a question of attitude
results.creator_credit: Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation, Max Pepper and Pepper Audio Visual
results.brief_description: In a series of dramatised sequences the importance of developing sensible attitudes to driving a motor vehicle is clearly presented. Aggressive and timid drivers, speeding away from traffic lights, poor driving techniques, “tailgating” and drink-driving are all dealt with.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation, Max Pepper and Pepper Audio Visual

results.title: Play safe
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Dennis Hill Productions, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The fun of swimming and participating in water sports can be spoiled unless basic safety rules and techniques are known, practised and used. This comprehensive water safety film covers all aspects from drown-proofing to the use of life-jackets, to a full illustration of the Royal Life Saving Award technique of safe non-contact rescue. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Dennis Hill Productions, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Nest of Tens
results.brief_description: ‘Nest of tens’ is comprised of four alternating stories which reveal mundane yet personal methods of control. These systems are derived from intuitive sources. Children and a retarded adult operate control panels made out of paper, lists, monsters and their own bodies. ‘A young boy, home alone, performing a bizarre ritual with a baby; an uneasy, aborted sexual flirtation between a teenage babysitter and an older man; an airport lounge encounter between a businesswoman (played by July) and a young girl. Linked by a lecturer enumerating phobias in a quasi-academic seminar, these three perverse, unnerving scenarios involving children and adults provide authentic glimpses into the queasy strangeness that lies behind the everyday’. New York Video Festival, 2000.

results.title: The amateurist
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: A short, captivating video about surveillance, identity, watching and being watched. ‘The Amateurist’ slides along the edges of horror and satire to create an unsettling portrait of a woman on the brink of a technologically-driven madness.
results.description: A short, captivating video about surveillance, identity, watching and being watched. ‘The Amateurist’ slides along the edges of horror and satire to create an unsettling portrait of a woman on the brink of a technologically-driven madness.
